summary: Anuj Kapoor, a former employee on a CVS project in Rhode Island, filed the suit against Infosys in June, alleging the company made him work more than 1,000 hours of overtime without pay. The company responded in August, stating that the employee was an ‘hourly’ worker on an H1-B visa even though Infosys had listed him as a salaried employee in an application with the Department of Labor, a potential reason for its Wage and Hour Division to look into the case.

summary: Unilever's thermometer plant in Kodaikanal exposed many workers to mercury poisoning, without giving them any protective equipment or information about the disastrous health effects of mercury. This toxic mercury, dumped around the factory and in forests, continues to contaminate soil and groundwater, affecting thousands. The workers cannot afford private healthcare, and have been fighting since 2001, asking Unilever to clean up the toxic contamination, and to compensate them for their medical expenses.
judgment: In 2016, the Company agreed to provide undisclosed ex-gratia payments to 591 affected victims on 'humanitarian' grounds, which was recorded before the Madras HC. Pressure then mounted for cleaning up and soil remediation of mercury contaminated sites and adjoing forest areas in the region.
headline: https://qz.com/india/634953/hindustan-unilever-is-finally-paying-workers-who-say-they-were-poisoned-by-mercury-but-its-not-enough/

summary: Hindustan Unilever Employees Federation called the protest. The workers were from the Amli and Dapada factories in Dadra and Nagar Haveli, and said their wages were not at par with consumer goods companies such as Nestle and Colgate. They also objected to the company's management creating "sponsored unions" with whom it was reaching settlements which were being foisted on the entire workforce. The workers also wanted around 15 of their colleagues who had been given termination orders to be reinstated.
headline: https://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/workers-of-hul-protest-over-wages-outside-head-office-114110100004_1.html

summary: The immediate source of the conflict centered around the management's failure to pay the monthly Settlement Implementation Allowance which should have been paid to all union members. The management of the plant claimed that the workers had failed to comply with the clauses of the agreement and had indulged in various illegitimate activities such as ‘illegal’ strikes. The factory was closed, after workers confronted 18 company executives for 17 hours over payment of bonus. After fifty days, the company announced that the lockout was over. Upon rejoining, the workers were instructed them not to enter the plant before they had signed a statement that they had resigned from the Hindustan Lever Workers Union.
judgment: In October 2007, the IUF filed a case against Hindustan Unilever Ltd. with the UK NCP, claiming that the management’s actions constitute a breach of Articles of the OECD guidelines. In March 2008 the HLWU had filed a writ petition against the Assam Government as well as the HUL Management seeking a restraining order against the HUSS & HUL Management for signing any wage settlement. On 24th March the Guwahati High Court passed an Interim Order in favour of the HLWU.
headline: https://www.indiaretailing.com/2007/07/16/retail/hindustan-unilever-halts-factory-operations-in-assam/

summary: Workers at the Ranjangaon plant of ITC Foods went on strike in 2013 demanding higher wages. ITC Foods Employees Union represented the workers, demanding hike in wages from R10,000 to around R23,000 per month. The demand for hike in wages was part of the first wage agreement that the Union is negotiating with the company management.
headline: https://www.financialexpress.com/archive/itc-foods-ranjangaon-workers-go-on-strike-demanding-wage-hike/1140315/

summary: Workers formed a union in April 2009 in the face of aggressive union-busting. The strike was triggered by the removal of two probationers over performance. Subsequently, the Nestle management allegedly suspended four more workers, forcing the employees to go on an indefinite strike.
judgment: The management of the Nestle Pantangar factory was finally forced into mediation by the continued strike action by 150 permanent workers that was supported by 600 contract workers. The Assistant Labour Commissioner (ALC) facilitated negotiations between management and union representatives that was signed by all three parties.Despite attacks on the union and attempts by management to stop the union’s registration, the union succeeded in winning legal recognition and immediately joined the IUF-affiliated Federation. With the support of the Federation the Nestlé Pantnagar union won the right to wage bargaining.
headline: https://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/nestle-govt-attempt-to-end-strike-109050900026_1.html

summary: In November 2008, the unions, which are members of the IUF-affiliated Federation of All India Nestle Employees, called for an end to the system of unilaterally imposed annual wage increments and demanded the right to negotiate wages. Nestlé India management refused to negotiate and instead obtained court injunctions permanently banning union actions within 50 to 200 metres of four factories (Moga, Samalkha, Ponda and Bicholim), effectively denying Nestle India workers their fundamental right of assembly.
judgment: This led to an escalation of the campaign, and following continuous pressure at local, national and international levels, Nestlé India finally entered into wage negotiations - a major step towards genuine recognition and respect of trade union rights after decades of rights violations.
headline: http://cms.iuf.org/?q=node/170

summary: Close to 5,000 workers  went on strike on December 11, 2013, demanding the payment of performance-based incentive. However, the management is insisting on the basis of the company's operating profit, which is against the MoU signed by the company with the Ministry of Defence." The primary area of disagreement between the two sides was about the manner in which incentive payments ought to be computed.

summary: Workers in the nine units of the Defence PSU Bharat Electronics Ltd (BEL) went on strike on March 2 2016, demanding settlement of Pension Scheme for the permanent workers. Protestors argued that there should be no structural discrimination between officers and workers atleast in matter of superannuaton benefits. "While huge difference exists in wages and benefits between officers and workers, the same cannot be tolerated in matters of post retiremet benefits." The management had previously committed to the workers at its JSC meetings that, same and similar pension scheme will be implemented to the workers.
